author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Visit the Louvre and Christina Tosi’s Kitchen
description: See the Mona Lisa, up your baking skills and get some answers to your salacious questions about dinosaurs.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What’s the Best Way to Make a Noise Complaint Against My Neighbor?
description: Noise complaints are often difficult to win, but there are some avenues to pursue that can work.
content: Q: I live in a Harlem condo. The owner of the neighboring unit rents out her apartment to a tenant who runs her air-conditioner all day and night. The unit is directly outside my bedroom window. During the day I don’t mind the hum, but at night the noise is unbearable if I open my window. I reached out to the owner of the apartment, who claimed the tenants agreed to put the air-conditioner on a low setting at night. But they haven’t done so. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Rhyne, Sheri Fink and Emma Cott
title: ‘I Can Barely Keep Track’: Texas Hospital Battles Coronavirus Surge
description: Our correspondent Sheri Fink goes behind the scenes at Houston Methodist Hospital as coronavirus cases rise.
content: Our correspondent Sheri Fink goes behind the scenes at Houston Methodist Hospital as coronavirus cases rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Cleveland Indians Say They Will ‘Determine Best Path Forward’ on Name
description: The announcement came hours after the Washington Redskins of the N.F.L. made a similar statement. Both teams have been the subject of protests and criticism from Native Americans and others.
content: After decades of resisting calls to change their team name, the Cleveland Indians announced on Friday that they were willing to engage in discussions about whether the name is appropriate in the wake of national calls for social justice and reform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Sorting Out Canada’s Patchwork of Face Mask Rules
description: Without general directives from federal and provincial governments, local leaders have been left setting mask directives.
content: This year the hordes of visitors that usually flood into Ottawa for Canada Day were absent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Fourth of July Celebrations Dulled by Soaring Coronavirus Cases
description: Many Americans, fearful of the virus, stayed at home and held muted celebrations, although some went on undeterred.
content: Fear hung over the Fourth of July holiday this year as the worsening coronavirus pandemic caused many Americans to pull back from their usual celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: 3 Officers Fired Over Photos Taken Near Elijah McClain Memorial
description: The Aurora, Colo., police chief said the officers mocked the death of Mr. McClain, a 23-year-old massage therapist who died several days after officers put him in a chokehold last summer.
content: Three Aurora, Colo., police officers have been fired over photos that show two of them grinning and mocking the death of Elijah McClain, a 23-year-old massage therapist who was arrested and placed in a chokehold last August. Mr. McClain died several days later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerry Mullany
title: Severe Flooding in Southern Japan Swamps Nursing Home
description: Officials said that at least 16 people had died as a result of the deluge and mudslides that struck the island of Kyushu overnight.
content: Torrential rains in southern Japan caused widespread flooding and mudslides on Saturday, with at least 16 people dead as officials warned 75,000 residents to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: How the Republican Convention Created Money Woes in Two Cities
description: Donors are wondering why they gave to a Charlotte event that has mostly been scrapped. And Jacksonville fund-raisers find money is on hold because of concerns about the surge in virus cases.
content: WASHINGTON — The abrupt uprooting of the Republican National Convention from Charlotte to Jacksonville has created a tangled financial predicament for party officials as they effectively try to pay for two big events instead of one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Attacks in Somalia Leave at Least 5 Dead
description: Devastating assaults, occurring almost daily and often in the capital, Mogadishu, have put a strain on the country’s fragile government.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Attacks in two of Somalia’s largest cities killed five people and wounded 16 others Saturday, in the latest example of the chronic failure of the country’s security sector to crack down on terrorist groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Masahiro Tanaka Struck by Ball as Yankees Take Health Hit
description: In a harrowing first workout of the summer, the Yankees starting pitcher was struck on Saturday. Later, the team announced that All-Star infielder D.J. LaMahieu and pitcher Luis Cessa tested positive for Covid-19.
content: Saturday was the Yankees’ first official summer workout, a routine bit of preparation to start their coronavirus-shortened 2020 season. Instead of an ordinary practice at Yankee Stadium, the team witnessed a frightening incident in which a key pitcher was hit on the head with a line drive. And later in the day, it announced that two other players were absent from practice because they had tested positive for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: With Beijing’s Military Nearby, U.S. Sends 2 Aircraft Carriers to South China Sea
description: The deployment of an American aircraft carrier and its strike force is often used as a signal to deter adversaries. Deploying two at once is recognized as a significant show of force.
content: WASHINGTON — Two American aircraft carriers sailed to the South China Sea on Saturday for what Navy officials described as a freedom-of-navigation operation while China’s military conducts exercises nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma and Edward Wong
title: New Trump Appointee Puts Global Internet Freedom at Risk, Critics Say
description: A battle involving Michael Pack and a U.S.-funded tech group revolves around software from Falun Gong, the secretive, anti-Beijing spiritual movement with pro-Trump elements.
content: WASHINGTON — When Michael Pack, a conservative filmmaker and ally of Stephen K. Bannon, recently fired the heads of four U.S. government-funded news outlets, many became alarmed that he would turn the independently operated organizations, as well as the Voice of America, into “Trump TV.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: As Coronavirus Slams Houston Hospitals, It’s Like New York ‘All Over Again’
description: The death toll is lower, but there are echoes of March as cases spike, doctors fall ill and supplies run short. Now, Texas is trying to adapt hard-won lessons while addressing a new set of challenges.
content: HOUSTON — Over the past week, Dr. Aric Bakshy, an emergency physician at Houston Methodist, had to decide which coronavirus patients he should admit to the increasingly busy hospital and which he could safely send home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: In North Korea, Coronavirus Hurts More Than Any Sanctions Could
description: Closing the border with China crippled the regime’s few remaining methods, legal and otherwise, for bringing in much-needed foreign currency.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — On New Year’s Day, North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, called for a “frontal breakthrough to foil the enemies’ sanctions.” The strategy meant finding new sources of income, legal or illegal, and mainly from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Family Romance, LLC’ and Fireworks
description: Werner Herzog’s documentary explores Japan’s rent-a-family industry. And fireworks displays will be broadcast from New York and Washington.
content: FAMILY ROMANCE, LLC (2019) Stream on Mubi. You may not be able to choose your family, but a thriving rental industry in Japan allows you to get pretty close. In his latest film, a hybrid work of fiction and documentary, Werner Herzog goes inside the country’s rent-a-family industry, which pairs actors with those in need of a replacement relative, spouse or friend — for a fee. The film follows Ishii Yuichi, the founder of the rental company Family Romance, and the various roles he plays to fill the voids in his clients’ lives. Things get complicated when Yuichi takes a job portraying a young girl’s missing father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman, Elizabeth Paton, Jessica Testa and Guy Trebay
title: The Unsung Heroes of Fashion, Now Mostly Unemployed
description: In a pre-coronavirus world, hundreds of editors, clients, stylists and celebrities would have converged on Paris this weekend, clacking over the cobblestones in their kitten heels for the couture shows. Those singular displays of fashion art — handmade clothes custom-ordered by the very few — represent equal parts creative laboratory, artisanal expertise and visual extravaganza. For many, they are also a major employment opportunity.
content: In a pre-coronavirus world, hundreds of editors, clients, stylists and celebrities would have converged on Paris this weekend, clacking over the cobblestones in their kitten heels for the couture shows. Those singular displays of fashion art — handmade clothes custom-ordered by the very few — represent equal parts creative laboratory, artisanal expertise and visual extravaganza. For many, they are also a major employment opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: If a Zoom Wedding Isn’t for You, Here’s How to Plan For Later
description: Just got engaged? Here are a few tips from industry experts on how to plan an in-person wedding celebration next year.
content: After spending the last several months canceling, downsizing and postponing weddings, event planners remain cautiously optimistic about forging ahead now that some event restrictions are being lifted. While many couples have resorted to virtual wedding celebrations on Zoom, recently engaged couples who are planning their weddings for next year are hoping to celebrate with friends and family in person. Even as many states begin to gradually lift the restrictions aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus, events of all types will have to adjust to new health and safety practices. We asked industry experts to share some of their planning recommendations for recently engaged couples who are looking to celebrate their union, without Zoom, next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon create a tenuous work environment.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt involves a subject close to my heart! It’s from a recent work of fiction called “Temporary” by the writer Hilary Leichter, whom I’d never heard of. I looked her up on my library app, borrowed the book in a couple of clicks and read most of it the same evening I solved this. It’s fun and kind of experimental — if you’re intrigued by the passage, give it a try.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and David Scull
title: Your Weekend Briefing: Halfway Through 2020
description: January feels like a decade ago. Here’s what you may have forgotten.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and David Scull
title: Your Weekend Briefing: Halfway Through 2020
description: January feels like a decade ago. Here’s what you may have forgotten.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Tennis Tours Debate Ranking Systems Frozen by the Coronavirus
description: The rankings have key implications for tournament seedings and sponsor bonuses.
content: For professional tennis players, the coronavirus pandemic has meant canceled tournaments, lost income and frozen rankings, with the men’s and women’s tours putting their systems on hold in mid-March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: A Teacher Held a Famous Racism Exercise in 1968. She’s Still at it.
description: The day after Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, Jane Elliott carried out the “Blue Eyes, Brown Eyes” exercise in her classroom. Now, people are returning to her work.
content: — Jane Elliott, a schoolteacher turned anti-racism educator
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nana Asfour
title: I Miss My Father’s Mind
description: Was he one of the hidden victims of the coronavirus pandemic?
content: The day after my father died unexpectedly at a rehabilitation center in May, I went searching through my microcassettes for the tapes he’d sent me many years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Beyond Broadway, the Show Does Go On
description: Watching through windshields. Audiences of two. An elbow bump instead of a kiss. Theaters across the country find novel ways to play in a pandemic.
content: Inside a former firehouse in Richmond, Va., a lone actor performs “The Picture of Dorian Gray” for audiences as small as two. In a Denver parking lot, theatergoers in cars watch, through their windshields, four performers costumed as grasshoppers. On a 600-acre property in Arkansas, a cast of about 130 re-enacts the story of Jesus for several hundred ticket-holders spread across a 4,000-seat outdoor amphitheater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: Caribbean, Struggling in the Pandemic, Braces for Hurricane Season
description: Scientists predict this hurricane season will be severe. But countries in the region, with economies burdened by the pandemic and the devastation of past hurricanes, have not been able to fully prepare.
content: MEXICO CITY — Houses with no roofs. Neighborhoods lacking electricity. Residents who fled still in exile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Life on the Vice-Presidential Short List
description: It’s exciting. It can also feel like a colonoscopy.
content: There will be blood tests. Interrogations about junior high. An analysis of tax returns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson
title: Sleeping Outside in a Pandemic: Vulnerable Renters Face Evictions
description: As the coronavirus prevents people from going back to work and paying their rent, evictions have begun, often targeting vulnerable people such as unauthorized immigrants.
content: After dark on a warm night this spring, Wilfredo Avila and his girlfriend Patricia Carillo lumbered toward the park near their apartment in Washington, D.C., their arms heavy with plastic bags filled with their clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump Says He Will Create a Statuary Park Honoring ‘American Heroes’
description: The executive order includes John Adams, Harriet Tubman and Martin Luther King Jr. among those who would be honored. So would Billy Graham, Antonin Scalia and Ronald Reagan.
content: President Trump ordered the federal government late Friday to design and construct a statuary park honoring “American heroes,” his latest embrace of American heritage in opposition to what he has described as a revolutionary leftist movement that would “erase our values.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: The Pandemic’s Big Mystery: How Deadly Is the Coronavirus?
description: Even with more than 500,000 dead worldwide, scientists are struggling to learn how often the virus kills. Here’s why.
content: More than six months into the pandemic, the coronavirus has infected more than 11 million people worldwide, killing more than 525,000. But despite the increasing toll, scientists still do not have a definitive answer to one of the most fundamental questions about the virus: How deadly is it?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 4, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 4, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about planned congressional testimony by Geoffrey S. Berman, the former top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to his role at the time of his dismissal. He was the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York; he was no longer the acting U.S. attorney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Black in America, Through a Camera
description: In a photography show and auction Jamel Shabazz and others take an up-close look at Black culture and community.
content: It would look like an improvised family gathering, children in the foreground, elders stalwart at the rear, were it not for the masks and kaleidoscopically colorful costumes. Those are central to a group portrait by Joshua Kissi, the image captured last winter at Mardi Gras, its subjects draped in a raucous mélange of Native and Afro-American ceremonial garb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Interpreting More Than Words for a Baseball Star
description: At one point, Bryan Lee, the interpreter for the Toronto Blue Jays ace Hyun-jin Ryu, was not cutting his hair or changing his T-shirt, to be in sync with the pitcher.
content: Bryan Lee struggled recently to remember when exactly he had first arrived in Dunedin, Fla. After some prodding, he placed it: Feb. 4, an eon ago in the brain-bending timeline of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Newt Gingrich and the Dawn of a Toxic Political Era
description: In “Burning Down the House,” Julian Zelizer shows how Gingrich was able to exploit the profound developments since Watergate to his lasting advantage.
content: To hear President Trump use the term, “corruption” can do double duty as a hand grenade and a safe word — a ready-made epithet to yell out whenever he’s feeling the squeeze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Théophile Larcher
title: Marc Fumaroli, Defender of French Culture, Is Dead at 88
description: A leading historian, he wrote and taught in defense of the French language and its heritage and against “globish English.”
content: PARIS — Marc Fumaroli, a leading French historian, public intellectual and defender of the French language and culture against American influence and what he called “globish English,” died on June 24 in Paris. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pick Your Tofu: Crispy or Baked
description: Yewande Komolafe’s tofu recipes, Melissa Clark’s grilled chicken thighs, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas (above), her recipe for baked tofu with peanut sauce and coconut-lime rice and Melissa Clark’s gingery grilled chicken thighs. Find more recipes in this collection for the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Joey Chestnut and Miki Sudo Again Set Hot Dog Eating Records
description: Even with a diminished field, the two competitive eaters put on an impressive showing in the annual event, which was held in a private location with coronavirus provisions this year.
content: Joey Chestnut and Miki Sudo bolstered their impressive resumes on Saturday by setting world records at Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog-Eating Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: This Year’s Summer Campground: Our Bedrooms and Living Rooms
description: Summer camp in the pandemic looks just like a screen. But what happens when kids run away from the computer?
content: Children at Interlochen Arts Camp in Michigan are doing all the usual this summer. They are taking dance and acting classes, learning to tie knots and weaving friendship bracelets. On some days, they sing campfire songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kisselgoff
title: Nikolai Fadeyechev, Elegant Bolshoi Dancer, Is Dead at 87
description: He was acclaimed for his noble style, and for being a partner who showed off his ballerinas and did not compete with them.
content: Nikolai Fadeyechev, one of the Bolshoi Ballet’s greatest dancers, who was hailed for his distinctive noble style and his chivalry as a partner to the Russian company’s leading ballerinas from the 1950s to the ’70s, died on June 23 in Moscow. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soledad O'Brien
title: Soledad O’Brien: A MeToo Moment for Journalists of Color
description: We’re finally feeling empowered to speak openly about racism in the newsroom.
content: Every journalist of color has a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yunghi Kim
title: To Be Hungry in the Middle of the Pandemic
description: In the neighborhoods most devastated by the coronavirus, food insecurity has emerged as a major concern.
content: In the best of times, life in New York City can be unforgiving. It was hard enough, working full tilt, to cover rent, child care and food before the pandemic. Now, in the neighborhoods most devastated by the coronavirus, life has become more precarious. And the most elemental human need — food — has become a pressing, urgent concern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: With Plexiglass and Piles of Hot Dogs, a Fourth of July Tradition Lives On
description: “They’re going to be burping and groaning, and I’m just going to have to focus on my hot dogs,” the 2020 Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest champion mused ahead of the quieter, crowd-free competition.
content: With Independence Day celebrations canceled around the country, one distinctly American tradition continued on Saturday despite the pandemic: the annual pilgrimage of competitive eaters to Coney Island for the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest. But with cheering crowds turned away to promote social distancing, contestants instead chowed down amid a chorus of gulping and chewing from their competitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In West Texas, Lingering Distrust in Public Health Measures as Virus Spreads
description: Early in the pandemic, much of rural Texas had low case counts and few worries. Now, conservative areas are seeing a surge in cases, but distrust in government mandates endure.
content: LUBBOCK, Texas — For a while, it seemed that the coronavirus had spared West Texas. Cases were low. Few had died. Concern through the spring was focused on getting businesses running again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: DNA Linked to Covid-19 Was Inherited From Neanderthals, Study Finds
description: The stretch of six genes seems to increase the risk of severe illness from the coronavirus.
content: A stretch of DNA linked to Covid-19 was passed down from Neanderthals 60,000 years ago, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: How’s Your Quarantine? If No One’s Banging Gongs, Count Your Blessings
description: At one South Korean hotel, hundreds of quarantined foreigners are enduring noisy daily protests from local residents, who want them out.
content: YONGIN, South Korea — Spending two weeks quarantined in a hotel room is not a pleasant experience, as thousands of people who’ve flown internationally since the pandemic began can attest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Nash
title: Women Ask Themselves, ‘How Can I Do This for One More Day?’
description: Portraits of those who are making it work.
content: The value of women’s work, both paid and unpaid, has never been more apparent than during the coronavirus crisis. As Diane Coyle recently noted in The Times, women’s shift into paid employment was one of the great economic transformations in recent history, but it did not free women from their myriad unpaid roles as caregivers, homemakers and community volunteers. These six women talked to The Times about what it’s like to straddle that divide. Their quotes have been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: 239 Experts With 1 Big Claim: The Coronavirus Is Airborne
description: The W.H.O. has resisted mounting evidence that viral particles floating indoors are infectious, some scientists say. The agency maintains the research is still inconclusive.
content: The coronavirus is finding new victims worldwide, in bars and restaurants, offices, markets and casinos, giving rise to frightening clusters of infection that increasingly confirm what many scientists have been saying for months: The virus lingers in the air indoors, infecting those nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: At Mt. Rushmore and the White House, Trump Updates ‘American Carnage’ Message for 2020
description: His ominous remarks were a reflection of his political standing: trailing in the polls, lacking a booming economy or a positive message to campaign on, and leaning on culture wars to buoy his loyalists.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump used the spotlight of the Fourth of July weekend to sow division during a national crisis, denying his failings in containing the worsening coronavirus pandemic while delivering a harsh diatribe against what he branded the “new far-left fascism.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Hosts July 4 Event at White House as U.S. Coronavirus Cases Soar
description: Hospitals in Houston near capacity. Iraq’s health care system is on the verge of breakdown. The Supreme Court rejected Illinois Republicans’ request to hold big political gatherings.
content: After delivering a divisive speech at Mount Rushmore on Friday night, President Trump hosted a Fourth of July event in Washington on Saturday, again waving away objections from some officials and public health experts who were worried the virus could spread through the events’ crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Some Revel in the Surf. Others Fear a New Wave.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 4, 2020.
content: “I haven’t been out for a long time. I feel like I’m free again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Unwavering
description: Peter Wentz pelts us with misdirects — gird your loins!
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Peter Wentz constructs a mean themeless grid, and today’s was particularly cruel to this solver, in several places. I was semi-convinced of the presence of multiple, unrelated rebuses in the northeast corner, because none of my best guesses quite fit. Elsewhere, a few of my more confident shots, made at the beginning of the endeavor, turned out to be misfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: Where You Can See the Stars of ‘Hamilton’ Now
description: Since their time in the Broadway show, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Leslie Odom Jr. and company have gone on to movies, TV and theater.
content: When a hip-hop musical chronicling the life of a Treasury secretary made its way uptown to Broadway in 2015, a fair number of the faces onstage were still relatively unknown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Blackburn
title: See Science Fly
description: Make this newspaper into a paper airplane. The sky’s the limit.
content: The best things about paper airplanes are that they allow you to be creative and that paper is easily accessible. You can use any type of paper — like this newspaper. That allows you to try lots of things and see what happens — opening the door to creativity and seeing science fly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: This July 4th, Consider Switching To Glow Sticks
description: Maybe don’t give a toddler a sparkler.
content: Last summer we were celebrating the Fourth of July with our closest friends. I’m sorry to report that this anecdote is going to get real gendered, so strap in. The moms were inside talking over the remnants of dessert, while the dads were outside with the kids lighting sparklers. A dad who will remain nameless handed my 2-year-old a sparkler. You know where this is going: Cue her running back inside the apartment crying because her tiny fingers were burned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Kimberly Guilfoyle, Top Fund-Raising Official for Trump Campaign, Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: She is the third person in proximity of President Trump known to have contracted the virus.
content: Kimberly Guilfoyle, the girlfriend of President Trump’s eldest son and a top fund-raising official for the Trump re-election campaign, tested positive for the coronavirus on Friday before a Fourth of July event at Mount Rushmore, a person familiar with her condition said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: 8 Picture Books That Let Young Minds Wonder and Wander on Their Own
description: These journeys of the imagination explore what it means to be human.
content: I DREAM OF A JOURNEY
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: To-Do List
description: Laura Taylor Kinnel’s puzzle makes us multitask.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We have a number of constructors who work in academia, and it makes sense that their puzzles might have some scholarly flair. Laura Taylor Kinnel teaches math and is the director of studies at a Friends boarding school in Pennsylvania, and was recently featured in a local news segment about how constructing and solving gives the brain a nice boost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: The Anthem Debate Is Back. But Now It’s Standing That’s Polarizing.
description: As games return and dozens of players drop to one knee, leagues that once tried to tiptoe around the issue won’t be able to avoid it.
content: A strange thing happened while most professional sports were away, shuttered by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times
